titles.title: LIN-RES project: Genomic analysis of linezolid resistance in strains isolated from healthy animals and human patients

dates.dateInformation: Poster presented at ASM 2021 World Microbe Forum, abstract number 56

descriptions.description: Linezolid is a critically important antibiotic to fight human infections caused by multi-resistant Gram-positive bacteria such as MRSA and VRE. Linezolid resistance can be caused by point mutations in the 23SrRNA gene and by plasmid-borne genes: cfr, optrA and poxtA. While linezolid is not licenced for use in food-producing animals, linezolid resistant isolates were retrieved from food-producing animals in different European countries including Belgium. The project aims to assess the occurrence of linezolid resistance in enterococci and staphylococci in 2019 in Belgium with a selective culture method. Another endpoint is to investigate the genetic environment associated with the linezolid-resistant phenotype and the relatedness of the isolates. Linezolid resistance occurrence ranged in faecal samples from 0% in turkeys to 16.4% in veal calves and reached up to 25.7% in nasal samples from fattening pigs. WGS results showed that linezolid-resistant staphylococci carried only the cfr gene while three genes were found in linezolid-resistant enterococci: cfr, poxtA and optrA. MLST analysis revealed 28 and 32 different sequence types for Enterococcus faecalis and E. faecium respectively. The study reveals a reservoir of plasmid-borne linezolid-resistance genes in the agricultural sector with potential for cross-selection by other antibiotics including phenicols.

Healthy animal faecal samples from broilers (n=295), turkeys (n=86), laying hens (n=205), breeding poultry (n=163), veal calves (n=293) and pigs (n=283) and sows and fattening pigs nasal swabs samples (n=78 and 70 respectively) were collected during 2019 through the official Belgian monitoring of antimicrobial resistance for enterococci and staphylococci and subcultivated on blood agar plates supplemented with linezolid (4mg/L) for 44h to 48h at 37°C. Two colonies of each positive samples were isolated and identified by MALDI-TOF. For each sample, one isolate per bacterial species was conserved and the linezolid resistance was quantified by broth microdilution (Sensititre). Three MRSA from previous monitoring and isolates recovered from human samples (4 enterococci and 1 MRSA) were added to the collection. Whole genome sequencing was performed on all the isolates to analyse the genetic organisation surrounding linezolid-resistance genes and for further relatedness analysis.

Poster presented at ASM 2021 World Microbe Forum (June 20-24, 2021), abstract number 56. Part of PhD02-LIN-RES project funded by the European Joint Programme One Health EJP under the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme, Grant Agreement No 773830.

ast.title: LIN-RES project: Genomic analysis of linezolid resistance in strains isolated from healthy animals and human patients
ast.introduction: Linezolid is a critically important antibiotic to fight human infections caused by multi-resistant Gram-positive bacteria such as MRSA and VRE. Linezolid resistance can be caused by point mutations in the 23SrRNA gene and by plasmid-borne genes: cfr, optrA and poxtA. While linezolid is not licenced for use in food-producing animals, linezolid resistant isolates were retrieved from food-producing animals in different European countries including Belgium. In this context, the project aims to assess the occurrence of linezolid resistance in enterococci and staphylococci in 2019 in Belgium with a selective culture method. Another endpoint of the project is to investigate the genetic environment associated with the linezolid-resistant phenotype and the relatedness of the isolates.
ast.methods: Healthy animal faecal samples from broilers (n=295), turkeys (n=86), laying hens (n=205), breeding poultry (n=163), veal calves (n=293) and pigs (n=283) and sows and fattening pigs nasal swabs samples (n=78 and 70 respectively) were collected during 2019 through the official Belgian monitoring of antimicrobial resistance for enterococci and staphylococci and subcultivated on blood agar plates supplemented with linezolid (4mg/L) for 44h to 48h at 37°C. Two colonies of each positive samples were isolated and identified by MALDI-TOF. For each sample, one isolate per bacterial species was conserved and the linezolid resistance was quantified by broth microdilution (Sensititre). Three MRSA from previous monitoring and isolates recovered from human samples (4 enterococci and 1 MRSA) were added to the collection. Whole genome sequencing was performed on all the isolates to analyse the genetic organisation surrounding linezolid-resistance genes and for further relatedness analysis.
ast.results: Linezolid resistance occurrence was ranging in faecal samples from 0% in turkeys to 16.4% in veal calves and reaching up to 25.7% in nasal samples from fattening pigs, all bacterial species combined. WGS and Resfinder results showed that linezolid-resistant staphylococci (n=7) carried only the cfr gene (n=7) while the three genes were found in linezolid-resistant enterococci (n=143): cfr (n=3), poxtA (n=36) and optrA (n=124). One poxtA was observed in a Pediococcus pentosaceus. All linezolid-resistant isolates lacking linezolid-resistance genes (n=4) contained 23S rRNA mutation. poxtA was not observed in the investigated human isolates. WGS results showed that cfr and optrA were often associated with fexA gene (resistance to phenicols) and that poxtA was associated with fexB (according to reads mapping analysis). Investigation of genetic organisation revealed 4 different organisations for cfr, 20 for optrA and one for poxtA. No differences were observed between animal and human isolates regarding the genetic organisations. In all cases, several resistance genes were carried by the isolates and in most cases, contigs carrying linezolid-resistance genes carried also other resistance genes (mostly resistance genes to phenicols and/or macrolides and/or aminoglycosides). MLST analysis was performed on the Staphylococcus aureus (n=6), Enterococcus faecalis (n=80) and Enterococcus faecium (n=48) isolates. Only one sequence type was observed for S. aureus, ST398. Regarding enterococci, 28 and 32 different STs were observed for E. faecalis and E. faecium respectively including new STs for both species.
ast.conclusions: Linezolid resistance is not so rare in animal isolates, revealing a reservoir of plasmid-borne linezolid-resistance genes in the agricultural sector. Moreover, the majority of the isolates carried also phenicol resistance genes. Several different organisations and sequence types were observed in the isolates collection. These observations revealed a large diversity of linezolid resistant isolates and a reservoir of bacteria susceptible to share linezolid resistance genes that could be cross-selected by other antibiotics including phenicols. Further investigation of relatedness between the isolates will be done through cgMLST and phylogenomic analysis. Conjugation assays will be done to investigate the transferability of the observed linezolid resistance genes.
ast.acknowledgements: This poster is part of the European Joint Programme One Health EJP. This project has received funding from the European Union's Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under Grant Agreement No 773830.

contentArray.title1: LIN-RES project: Genomic analysis of linezolid resistance in strains isolated from healthy animals and human patients. Linezolid is a critically important antibiotic to fight human infections caused by multi-resistant Gram-positive bacteria such as MRSA and VRE.
contentArray.title2: Methods: Healthy animal samples (broilers n=295, turkeys n=86, laying hens n=205, breeding poultry n=163, veal calves n=293, pigs n=283, sows and fattening pigs nasal swabs n=78 and 70) were collected during 2019 through official Belgian monitoring and subcultivated on blood agar plates supplemented with linezolid (4mg/L). Colonies identified by MALDI-TOF. Linezolid resistance quantified by broth microdilution. Three MRSA from previous monitoring and 5 human isolates added. Whole genome sequencing performed on all isolates.
contentArray.title3: Results: Linezolid resistance occurrence ranging from 0% in turkeys to 16.4% in veal calves and up to 25.7% in nasal samples from fattening pigs. Linezolid-resistant staphylococci (n=7) carried only cfr gene. Linezolid-resistant enterococci (n=143): cfr (n=3), poxtA (n=36) and optrA (n=124). Four different organisations for cfr, 20 for optrA and one for poxtA. MLST: S. aureus ST398, E. faecalis 28 different STs, E. faecium 32 different STs including new STs.
contentArray.title4: Genetic organisation: Figure shows most observed organisation of (A) poxtA (n=35/37), (B) cfr (n=7/10) and (C) optrA (n=24/124). Diagrams show gene arrangements with various resistance genes including fexA, fexB, and other associated genes.
contentArray.title5: Conclusion: Linezolid resistance not rare in animal isolates, revealing reservoir of plasmid-borne linezolid-resistance genes in agricultural sector. Majority of isolates also carried phenicol resistance genes. Large diversity observed. Further investigation through cgMLST and phylogenomic analysis planned. Conjugation assays to investigate transferability.

imageCaption.caption2: Genetic diagram showing poxtA gene organization with associated genes including fexA, fexB, and other resistance genes. Arrows indicate gene direction and organization on contigs.
